VOLUME XCV NUMBER 21

Spring Fair Accused of Discrimination
Chairs Reverse Decision to Reject Men's Group
by News-Letter staff
While making their way
through the whirlwind of preparations that accompany each year's
Spring Fair, Chairpersons Kelly
Mansfield and Rich Quarles were
confronted with an unexpected
menace: charges of discrimination.
The accusations were made by
Baltimore-based National Coalition of Free Men(NCFM), which
claims to have been the victim of
discrimination in the distribution
of booth space at this year's Fair.
The NCFM, which characterizes
itself as an "educational

organization that examines the
ways that sex discrimination affects men," applied for a space
at the Fair and received a firm rejection letter in early March.
After a series of phone calls
and letters questioning the rejection, the Fair chairs yesterday
reversed their decision, agreeing
to give space to the group. While
Fair's reasons for rejecting the
group's application remain hazy,
NCFM Chairman Jon Ryan
believes his organization was the
victim of sexual discrimination—
a violation of University policy.
In its rejection letter to the
group, Non-Profit Committee

Helen Hostin

Non-Profit Committee Co-Chairs Nini Sangrujee and Raquel Silverberg

Co-Chairs Nini Sangrujee and
Raquel Silverberg wrote: "Un-•
fortunately, we were unable to offer space to your organization.
This year the committee received an unprecedented number
of applications for a very limited
number of spaces in the NonProfit area." This was the extent
of the explanation for the group's
rejection.
Doubtful of the letter's sincerity, Ryan asked another member
of the NCFM to invent an
organization and to apply for nonprofit space at Fair. The member,
Jack Kammer, called the Spring
Fair office the following day to
inquire about booth space for the
ficticious group, which he called
Baltimore Men Against Rape and
Sexual Assault(BMARSA). According to Kammer, a Fair
representative told him that "they
were 'almost sure' there were
spaces available," and sent him
an application.
Kammer said that he received
the application shortly after, and
completed and mailed it on
March 11. Just over two weeks
later, Kammer said, a woman
who identified herself as Raquel
called to offer a booth to the
BMARSA. Kammer received an
acceptance letter for the group on
March 28.
On April 6, Ryan wrote a
three-page letter to Mansfield and
Quarles detailing both the rejection of the NCFM and acceptance

of the ficticious group presented
by Kammer. "Without question," he wrote, "I was lied to
about the deadline for applications and the availability of spaces
for non-profit organizations. .
Ryan continued, "I would like
to know what are the criteria or
guidelines that are used to determine which non-profit organization applicants are accepted and
which are denied space. If there
are no specific written criteria or
guidelines, are the determining
factors the judgement and/or personal prejudices of the Non-Profit
Committee Co-Chairs. ..?"
While Quarles and Mansfield
did not comment on Ryan's letter, they released a prepared
statement yesterday affirming
their decision to allow NCFM to
participate in the Fair. "After
receiving the [NCFM's] complaint," the statement read, "we
re-reviewed their application and
decided to accept [it] for the nonprofit area. We are currently
reviewing our criteria for the nonprofit area."
Dennis O'Shea of the University Office of News and Information confirmed the decision
to accept the application, adding
that the lack of specific criteria
for applicants had caused the problem. "From the beginning there
was no clear set of guidelines
governing the decisions," he
said.

Richardson Anticipates Large
Faculty Turnover by 21st Century
by Li-Yu Huang
By the year 2005, 340,000 new
faculty members will be needed
to replace all of those professors
who will have reached retirement
age, Johns Hopkins University
President William Richardson
said in a radio interview on
WJHU last Thursday. President
Richardson discussed this and
other current University issues in
a listener-interactive broadcast.
Using a question-answer
broadcast format, President
Richardson shared with the listening public his thoughts on the
future of Hopkins.
"It's going to be both an exciting decade and new century
and a challenging one," Richardson said. "Exciting in the sense

that the science and the other
scholarship that goes on in a
university like Hopkins are growing and exploding at an accelerated rate. So faculty and
students are challenged."
According to Richardson, one
of the many challenges he forsees
will be the hiring of new faculty.
"Because of the very large influx of faculty hiring in the 60's,
it is estimated that two-thirds of
our faculty in all the schools of
the University are retiring soon.
So we are faced with the
challenge of replacing them," he
said.

that a great amount of consideration and effort will be made to

SAC Groups Reprimanded

Seminar Cites Money Mismanagement
by Andy Prior
As a result of information
which came to light during SAC
budget hearing, ten SAC groups
were required to attend a seminar
on Wednesday to discuss financial irregularities.
In a memorandum to all SAC
groups, the SAC Executive Board
required the Black Student
Union, Bridge Club, Catholic
Community, Circle K, Class of
1992, HopSFA, Japanese
Students International, Korean
Students Association, and Outdoors Club to attend a Financial
Practices seminar or face "swift
and severe action against them,
including but not limited to barring them from potential Spring
Fair activities and freezing their
accounts." No groups were
absent.
The memorandum also stated
the Board's belief "that many
groups have not been acting

responsibly. . .[and are) out of
touch with standard procedures."
Many of the groups named
were discovered to be "spending
cash out of hand" rather than
making deposits and reporting income to Office of Student Activities Financial Coordinator
Shelley Albrecht. While conceding that this may be convenient for the groups, Albrecht
said there are "good reason for
record keeping." She cited the
need for records for future officers and insurance claims.
The Catholic Community,
which had been using money collected during masses for dinners
during the week, said that it did
not think it had to deposit it since
the money was church-related.
Special Interest Liaison Stephen
Kent Jusick said, however, that
as an SAC group the organization
is required to deposit all money
it takes in.
Circle K admitted to storing ap-

proximately $1400 from a carnation sale at a members apartment
for six weeks before finally
depositing the money. Telling the
group to deposit monies in a
timelier fashion, Albrecht expressed concern about the consequences if the apartment had been
burglarized.
HopSFA also spent cash out of
hand, using money from T-shirt
sales, as did the Class of 1992,
Japanese Student International,
and Outdoors Club. Most of the
groups claimed not to know that
what they had done was wrong.
Other groups are deeply in
debt.
The Choral Society, which did
not stop spending after its account
was frozen, is now $6,000 in debt
after starting the year only "a bit
[in debt]," according to Jusick.

Council Approves
Revised Constitution

Panhellenic To Begin
New Sorority Search

by Matt Rosengart
Student Council Secretary

by Neeli Ben-David

The Student Council discussion
focused on a revised constitution
at this week's meeting. Many
members have invested time this
semester, particularly this week,
studying sections felt to need
revision. Many changes have
been made, most significant of
which concerned the duties of the
executive positions and the
breakdown of groups in the SAC.
The newly revised constitution
passed with unanimity. Next
week, the newly-revised ByLaws will be brought up for approval. People who are interested
can attend the meeting.
The COC,chaired by Michelle
Wolf, presented its nominees for
Ethics Board. It reported twentyseven applicants for twelve positions. Council unanimously confirmed the following nominees
for Ethics Board: Jack Levy
(chairperson), John-Michael
Simpkins (presiding official),
Kathleen Curry, Jonathan Ko,
Timothy Min, Araba Quist, Matthew Schmelzer, Albert Su,
Simon Whang, and Barbara
White. In addition, the following
members were unanimously approved for CUS: Martine Sam,
David Ross, and Bill Van Home
as alternate.
The Budget Proposal for the
1991-1992 academic year was approved by the General Assembly
of the SAC. All classes were
given a 51
/
2 percent increase over
last year's budgets. A depreciation fund has been established for
those groups with equipment that
might possibly fail during the
year. This money is only

allocated to service such equipment in the event of its breaking
and is to serve no other purpose.
The budget passed unanimously.
$500 was allocated to assist the
Board of Elections in financing
the upcoming class elections.
Voting machines will be placed
in the breezeway from 11:00 to
5:00 p.m., in MSE from 5:00 to
9:00 p.m., and in AMRII from
11:00 to 9:00 p.m.
The Interfraternity Council
elected its new executive officers
for the 1991-1992 academic year.
The new officers are: President,
John Darre; Vice-President, Matt
Schmelzer; Treasurer, Dave
Morehaus; Secretary, Jennifer
Haussler. The IFC-sponsored
Escort Service begins April 16.
The HOP will sponsor its
largest event of the year Saturday,
April 13. The 2nd City Comedy
Show, accompanied by J.Q. and
the Bandits, will perform in
Shriver at 8:00 pm.
The Senior class has booked 41
rooms for its trip to Virginia
Beach. Seniors are advised to
watch for the Senior Class
Newsletter which should be appearing sometime next week.
The junior class will be selling
buffalo wings at the Spring Fair.
The sophomore class reported
an excellent turnout for their Croquet Tournament this past
weekend.
The freshman class made $300
at Monte Carlo Night. President
Colin Chellman will meet with
Dean Boswell this week to
discuss the recycling program for
next year. The class will also be
providing packets containing information about recycling to be
available in the dorms.

Avoiding the 'Tail End'
If numbers are where the action is, the Johns Hopkins Office of
Admissions can rightfully claim a victory with this year's applicant pool. Freshman applications were up 17 percent from last year,
an increase made even more impressive at a time when many—
including this publication—feared that the University's public image was in decline. The new admissions figures suggest otherwise:
obviously a new group of some of the country's best students is more
than willing to take its chances at Hopkins, and at a minimum of
$16,000 a year. Admissions has clearly done an excellent job of drawing a bevy of impressive applicants. Now the tricky part: Why is
it, as Director of Admissions Rit Fuller noted, that Johns Hopkins
is "at the tail end with our peer institutions in terms of accepted
students who enroll"?
One obvious answer is that Hopkins lacks the prestige of Harvard
or Yale or Stanford, which is not exactly news. But if the University
can't beat those schools at their own game—name brand recognition
and word-of-mouth advertising—it might try to make a name for itself
in some other categories.
Campus Diversity—Kobi Little's observation on page 2 that
Hopkins "is not keeping pace with other universities of its caliber"
on issues of minority recruiting and cultural awareness may seem
a tired issue, but it is undeniably correct. With all of the nascent
movements to promote awareness and tolerance within the University community, only the Black Student Union has been a consistent
advocate of more far-reaching recruiting efforts in the ongoing search
for qualified freshmen. Admissions can point proudly to its large,
varied Asian-American and foreign-student populations—why not extend the diversity further, and include greater numbers of AfricanAmericans and Hispanics? This is easier said than done, the NewsLetter realizes, but diversity and tolerance are also easier to appreciate
in an environment that puts its minorities in the majority.
Faculty Members—While the University continues to knock itself
out promoting its research-over-teaching ethic, discontent among
faculty members continues to move in silently and ominously, like
a fleet of enemy ships on the horizon. If President Richardson's incessant fundraising yields any fruit, it should go toward filling some
of the yawning holes in research and teaching-assistant funds—just
to name two—and as quickly as possible. Let no one in the administration think that a jump in applications means their work is finished,

or even relieved. Great minds and great teachers are being lost—
most recently William Freehling of the Department of History, who
took a position at another school because Hopkins, he said, is "a
research institution that doesn't give its faculty members what they
need to do research and teach responsibly." For those who didn't
know Dr. Freehling, imagine the loss of David Olton in Psychology,
Richard Macksey in the Humanities Center, or Steven David in
Political Science, and the void left by Freehling—especially in
teaching—is easier to appreciate. The University will have trouble
enough trying to replace one such talent. It ought to bend over
backwards to ensure that it doesn't lose another.
Community—Before Admissions sends out another of its elegantly
produced brochures to prospective students, it might consider asking the administration to loosen up the pursestrings for a new student union and a greater HOP budget, to name only two pressing
needs. More students at Hopkins take it for granted that their peers
are a little cold; that yeah, a lot are just plain jerks; and that they
don't often get a chance to meet people. It doesn't have to be so dire.
The News-Letter believes that a campus spot for after-hours dancing
and (yes, we'll say it) drinking would do wonders for the atmosphere
here at Hopkins. It may not be priority—student concerns never are—
but administrators looking for a more cohesive, active student community could hardly spend their money in a better way. And it will
pay off in spades when prospectives come and actually find the people having fun.
Disconnected as these three phenomena might seem; they all directly
affect the atmosphere at—and eventually the public image of—the
University. A diverse student population sets a good example for
other schools and suggests that Hopkins' commitment to providing
quality education is more than skin- or checkbook-deep. Support for
faculty members encourages better teaching, which yields bettereducated students, which yields a better image for the University.
And a more tightly knit student community would benefit everyone
from Admissions to Zeniada.
Small improvements? Perhaps. But if a better Johns Hopkins is
the goal—and we optimistically hope it is—we should shoot for standards that have more resonance than SAT scores, and more depth
than an Ivy League reputation. If that won't attract talented incoming freshmen, then perhaps we don't want 'em.

Every so often, a science
becomes popular. Not long ago,
it was biotechnology. Before that,
it was particle physics. Cellular
automata were pretty hip for a
while, and there was a time when
simply everyone was talking
about artificial intelligence. I
don't know who determines what
is worth studying, but I used to
try to keep tabs on what was "in"
by going to bookstores and looking for the big, colorful, and
science-related covers in the
bestseller section.
Manny, the guy at the
bookshop, always used to tell me,
"You know, I used to be a
famous physicist. Then I caught
on. There's no knowledge in real
science anymore. I'm twice the
man I used to be, now that I have
this little store. I've learned so
much!"
I nodded and took my receipt.
"Say Manny," I asked,"how do
you know what's next? I mean,
when you order all those science
bestsellers, how do you know
which ones will be hot and which
will be duds?"
Manny's voice became con-

spiratorial as he leaned toward
me. "That's the thing. I don't
decide which books to get.
They're sent to me."
"Who does it, Manny? Who
sends you the books? Are they
CIA? Mafia? Trilaterals?"
"No. Some place out in..."—
he looked over his shoulder—
"...Nebraska. I get a big crate of
them every so often. All the
books come wrapped in butcher's
paper with stickers that say 'Do
Not Open Before' some date."
"Have you ever opened one
before the date?"
Manny raised an eyebrow.
"No. Now that you mention it,
I haven't. Should I?"
I shrugged my shoulders,
thanked him for the book, and
shoplifted a set of small children
as I left. It was just another trip
to the bookstore for me, but
everything had changed for the
former physicist. That night, he
prematurely opened a package of
books and read all about the coming miracle of cybernetics. Suddenly, Manny found himself invited to all the good cocktail parties just so he could show off his
fashionable knowledge of cuttingedge science. Soon, he was addicted, tearing through cognitive
science books and astronomy
texts several months in advance,
using the best facts for party
gossip, and then selling the dregs
to wealthy doctoral students and
grant writers.
In the meantime, the bookshop
fell into ruin. The pimply youths

who now ran the store could only offer their customers yellowed
copies of self-help books and
Danielle Steele novels. And all
the while, Manny sent postcards
from the coolest resorts in Lower
Volta and Glen Burnie, suggesting that he was getting lots of
sex and drugs with big rock and
roll stars.
One day, I stopped by Manny's
store, but it was boarded up.
Signs in the otherwise-empty
windows said that the place
would soon be a Thai tie shop.
Two guys, each carrying a violin
case, walked behind me. They
spoke with that distinct
Nebraskan accent. I tried to stop
them on the street, but they
vanished into a crowd.
I puzzled over these goings-on,
and then went to find my friend
who was waiting at the mini-mall.
I had told her to stay there while
I looked into an answer to her attraction question. When I returned, she greeted me with a
flourish.
"What do you know about
nanotechnology?" she asked,
putting the flourish back in its
bag.
I smiled and reached down to
pet Nanotechnology, her new
dog.
No news is not good news.
At least not at the
News-Letter. If you'd
like to write news, call Amy
or Andy at 338-7647.

Curious About the Middle East?
Want to Learn How it all Started?
The Near Eastern Studies Department will be offering the following courses in the Fall Semester. Four of these courses are given
entirely in English, require no knowledge of a foreign language, and have no prerequisites:

130.101 (H) Ancient Near Eastern Civilizations (3), MW 10 Schwartz
An introduction to the entire ancient Near East, from the first prehistoric farming communities to Alexander the Great. Learn about
the first cities and the first empires known. Includes the Sumerians, Babylonians, Assyrians, Hittites, Hurrians, Israelites, Egyptians,
Phoenicians, and Persians. If you want to understand the roots of conflict in the Middle East, this is the place to start!

130.301 (H) History of Ancient Syria-Palestine, including Israel (3), M 3-5 McCarter
Focuses on the area of modern Syria, Lebanon, Israel and Jordan. Discover the great early civilizations of Syria, including the revolutionary
finds from Ebla. Learn how our own alphabet originated in the second millennium BC. Study the emergence of ancient Israel and its interaction
with its neighbors. Evaluate the Old Testament as a historical source. In this course, you will do it all!

130.305 (H) Law in the Ancient World (3), TTh 3 Westbrook
Our modern concepts of law and justice can be traced directly back to the ancient world. This course will survey the legal systems of the ancient
Near East and early Greece and Rome from the earliest known records through the fifth century BC. Reading assignments will focus on original
documents, like the Code of Hammurabi, in English translation. Taught by a lawyer, the course will compare the legal concepts of the world's
oldest known systems with those of modern law.

130.391 (H) Jewish Literature and Civilization (2), W 11-12:30 Smolar
Study Jewish literature in translation from early post-biblical times to the present as a mirror of religious and social development, political
theory, and philosophical diversity. Taught by the president of the Baltimore Hebrew University.
If you like learning new languages, and have been intrigued by Egyptian hieroglyphs or the wedge-shaped cuneiform signs on Babylonian clay
tablets, you might want to try the following courses. Although they have graduate numbers, undergraduates who apply themselves should have
no difficulty completing them successfully.

132.600 (H) Elementary Akkadian (4), TBA Westbrook
The language of ancient Babylonia and Assyria, written in cuneiform script. After an introduction to the script and grammar, beginners are
soon reading texts that form the basis of Western culture, such as the Flood story and the first great law code.

133.600 (H) Hieroglyphs: Script and Language of Ancient Egypt (4), TBA Galan
An introduction to Middle Egyptian, the classical language of Egyptian hieroglyphs. The same language that was written by King Tut and
Ramses the Great, it is taught at only a handful of universities. A year will make you conversant enough to read some short stories, a few of the
world's first medical texts, and inscriptions from statues in museums (amaze your friends!).
You may think you know Hebrew, but until you've studied the language of the Bible on its own terms, you only know part of the story. The
following course will introduce you to the Hebrew of the Bible, unencumbered by post-biblical accretions:

130.440 Elementary Biblical Hebrew (3), TBA Scott

Fifty Students Pack
Meals for Homeless
by Kathleen Curry
On March 14, shelters for the
homeless in the Baltimore City
area received bagged meals
assembled by fifty Hopkins
students. This initiative on the
part of Student Council was
organized by Freshman Class
Representative Margaret Lee,
who was asked to head the Food
Drive Committee at the beginning of second semester.
In less than two months, with
some advising from the United
Way, Lee raised enough funding
from local bakeries, grocery
stores, and a freshman class dorm
contest to bag over one thousand
lunches consisting of sandwiches,
popcorn, candy and an apple.
"I really didn't know anything
about Baltimore when I began
this project," said Lee. "So I
began by working with Dee Klein
at the United Way, and also made
an effort not to conflict with
Salvation Army programs."
The bags went to six shelters,
including St. Mark's, Antiarc,
and St. Anne's. Although the
Salvation Army offers a food van
service, there is still a great demand for resources from the
community.
"Many shelters are still in
need," explained Lee. "I think
they really appreciated seeing that
Hopkins cares."
Lee recognizes, however, that
campus awareness of issues concerning the greater Baltimore
community is always in need of
improvement.
"We have to recognize that
there is a whole world outside of
this campus. Apathy is probably

the biggest problem. People don't
know how much power they really have to affect change, but we
need to take an active interest in
making a difference because we
can, and we have."
Although Lee realizes that the
future of such programs will be
dependent on the new Student
Council's agenda, she would like
to see these efforts continued.
"I'd like to see a lot more
students get involved in community efforts to work against
poverty and homelessness," she
said.
Ms. Lee noted her great thanks
to the Student Council, Bob
Nelson, the United Way, and all
those who came to help bag the
meals.
"Everybody's contribution was
extremely important," she concluded. "I couldn't have accomplished this without their
support."

Men's Lacrosse Loses to Tarheels
by Jay Friedman
CHAPEL HILL, April 6—
It was one of the most anticipated games of the season.
Powerful offense against stifling
defense. The top two teams in
Division I lacrosse squared off in
a battle for national bragging
rights. Unfortunately for the Blue
Jays, the top-ranked Tar Heels of
the University of North Carolina
can brag—for now. The Tar
Heels defeated Hopkins 11-6
beneath a Carolina blue sky to remain undefeated and top ranked.
In a game that was closer than the
score indicated, Carolina (7-0)
used a third-quarter surge to pull
ahead of the Jays 8-4 in front of
5700 fans at Fetzer Field. At least
the Blue Jays finished the
toughest stretch of their schedule
(Syracuse in the Carrier Dome,
then No. 1 UVa, and at NO. 1
UNC)with two victories. That's
two more than the experts
predicted before the season
started as all three teams were
ranked above Hopkins. At 4-2 on
the year the Jays are now the
fourth ranked team, behind
Carolina, Princeton, and Brown.
Hopkins jumped out to a 2-0
lead 4 minutes and 38 seconds into the game on goals 29 seconds

apart. Junior Jeff Wills opened
the scoring off a cross field feed
from Matt Panetta. After the goal
Carolina was called for unnecessary roughness and the Jays
scored on the ensuing extra-man
opportunity. Panetta, at the top of
the restraining box, found Seth
Tierney, playing with a broken
wrist for the second week, in
front of the cage where he released a five-yard shot over UNC
goalie Andy Piazza's shoulder.
The Hopkins offense looked like
it was about to continue where it
left off after last week's Virginia
victory but that was not to be.
Playing on their home grass
field (beautifully manicured to
look like a golf fairway), the Tar
Heels used their deep bench and
overall team speed to control the
tempo of the game until the final
buzzer. After tying the game two
minutes later on goals 18 seconds
apart, UNC began dictating play.
Although the Heels did do a good
job of keeping Hopkins in the
game thoughout the first half by
failing to convert several fast
break opportunities and missing
the 6x6 on still more, they seemed to be slowly taking control of
the game. The final statistics
would suggest the same; the Jays
were outshot 51-35 for the after-

noon. Of those, Hopkins put 23
on net compared to Carolina's 31.
Given the chance, Hopkins
took the lead back at 3-2 on an
incredibly no-angle shot by Brendan Cody. The play was a great
individual effort but it marked the
beginning of the end. Without the
cutting and the movement from
the other players on the offensive
end the Jays were bound to get into trouble. But while Hopkins
looked to get back in the swing
they were missing their own
chances, too. Hopkins hit the pipe
on at least three occasions in the
first half. Any one of those could
have been a goal, and an important one, but the bounces were not
going the Blue Jay way.
As both teams did their best to
keep the game close, Carolina
started to crank up a talented offense led by Michael Thomas and
John Webster. With the transition
game getting into gear, Carolina
was getting into what they do
best. "They live and die by controlling the tempo," noted Blue
Jay coach Tony Seaman. And that
is exactly what happened. Both
Thomas and Webster recorded
three goals and one assist on the
day. Meanwhile, Brian Voelker
and Scott Giardina did their best
to keep the Jays in the fight.

preliminary heats, both the men's
heavyweight four and the
women's novice eight failed to
qualify for the finals, while the
women's heavyweight four did
not compete because of an injury
to one of its rowers.
The men's lightweight eight
gave the small but vocal crowd
of Hopkins supporters plenty of
excitement when they fell behind
early to George Washington, but
the men's eight maintained its
composure, gradually overtaking
George Washington for the win.
"I was really pleased with the
way we rowed, because when we
fell behind early we didn't panic.
That was an area we were hoping to improve in from last week.
When we needed power, we got
it, and we managed to gain on,
and eventually take George
Washington," said senior cocaptain Rob Porcarelli.
Unfortunately for Hopkins, the
other boats of the crew failed to
match the success of the
lightweight eight, most likely due
to the fact that Hopkins was
distracted by having to host the
regatta. As host, the members of
the crew were responsible for
such logistics as assembling the
course, repairing the starting
docks, handling concessions at
the race, and providing lodging
for over 150 visiting rowers. The
distractions of hosting the regatta were a definite handicap for
some of Hopkins' rowers.
"We definitely expected to do
a lot better," said junior Eric

Plautz, a member of the men's
heavyweight four. "I think
hosting tired us out mentally and
physically. It was draining
because there were a lot of things
to do and worry about."
Although the women's novice
eight failed to qualify for the
finals, freshman coxswain
Stephanie Fishkin felt her boat
continued to gain experience at
the regatta.
"I think we rowed really well
last week. I see a lot of improvement each week we row, and I
think we're going to continue to
get better," said Fishlcin.
The overall Hopkins performance was most certainly affected by the absence of the
women's heavyweight four,
which was expected to cruise to
an easy victory at the Invitational.
The women's four was forced to
withdraw when a team member,
junior Jen Ehringer, developed
back problems.
"It was really disappointing not
being able to row because we
knew we could win, but it was
just one of those things you can't
control," said senior Kathleen
McCabe, a rower on the
women's four.
The women's four hopes to
have Ehringer back this week so
they can row at the George
Washington Invitational, where
they will face such crews as
George Washington and Carnegie
Mellon. The race is especially
important for the women because
its results help to determine the
all-important seedings for the
Dad Vail Regatta at the end of the
year.
The men's heavyweight four
will hope to improve upon last
week's performance although
they will face a very competitive
field, including boats from
Georgetown, Navy, and George
Washington.
"I think we've had a few problems that we've worked out, so
I think we have a good chance of
doing fairly well," said Plautz.

Spring Fair Accused of Discrimination
Chairs Reverse Decision to Reject Men's Group
by News-Letter staff
While making their way
through the whirlwind of preparations that accompany each year's
Spring Fair, Chairpersons Kelly
Mansfield and Rich Quarles were
confronted with an unexpected
menace: charges of discrimination.
The accusations were made by
Baltimore-based National Coalition of Free Men(NCFM), which
claims to have been the victim of
discrimination in the distribution
of booth space at this year's Fair.
The NCFM, which characterizes
itself as an "educational

organization that examines the
ways that sex discrimination affects men," applied for a space
at the Fair and received a firm rejection letter in early March.
After a series of phone calls
and letters questioning the rejection, the Fair chairs yesterday
reversed their decision, agreeing
to give space to the group. While
Fair's reasons for rejecting the
group's application remain hazy,
NCFM Chairman Jon Ryan
believes his organization was the
victim of sexual discrimination—
a violation of University policy.
In its rejection letter to the
group, Non-Profit Committee

Helen Hostin

Non-Profit Committee Co-Chairs Nini Sangrujee and Raquel Silverberg

Co-Chairs Nini Sangrujee and
Raquel Silverberg wrote: "Un-•
fortunately, we were unable to offer space to your organization.
This year the committee received an unprecedented number
of applications for a very limited
number of spaces in the NonProfit area." This was the extent
of the explanation for the group's
rejection.
Doubtful of the letter's sincerity, Ryan asked another member
of the NCFM to invent an
organization and to apply for nonprofit space at Fair. The member,
Jack Kammer, called the Spring
Fair office the following day to
inquire about booth space for the
ficticious group, which he called
Baltimore Men Against Rape and
Sexual Assault(BMARSA). According to Kammer, a Fair
representative told him that "they
were 'almost sure' there were
spaces available," and sent him
an application.
Kammer said that he received
the application shortly after, and
completed and mailed it on
March 11. Just over two weeks
later, Kammer said, a woman
who identified herself as Raquel
called to offer a booth to the
BMARSA. Kammer received an
acceptance letter for the group on
March 28.
On April 6, Ryan wrote a
three-page letter to Mansfield and
Quarles detailing both the rejection of the NCFM and acceptance

of the ficticious group presented
by Kammer. "Without question," he wrote, "I was lied to
about the deadline for applications and the availability of spaces
for non-profit organizations. .
Ryan continued, "I would like
to know what are the criteria or
guidelines that are used to determine which non-profit organization applicants are accepted and
which are denied space. If there
are no specific written criteria or
guidelines, are the determining
factors the judgement and/or personal prejudices of the Non-Profit
Committee Co-Chairs. ..?"
While Quarles and Mansfield
did not comment on Ryan's letter, they released a prepared
statement yesterday affirming
their decision to allow NCFM to
participate in the Fair. "After
receiving the [NCFM's] complaint," the statement read, "we
re-reviewed their application and
decided to accept [it] for the nonprofit area. We are currently
reviewing our criteria for the nonprofit area."
Dennis O'Shea of the University Office of News and Information confirmed the decision
to accept the application, adding
that the lack of specific criteria
for applicants had caused the problem. "From the beginning there
was no clear set of guidelines
governing the decisions," he
said.

Avoiding the 'Tail End'
If numbers are where the action is, the Johns Hopkins Office of
Admissions can rightfully claim a victory with this year's applicant pool. Freshman applications were up 17 percent from last year,
an increase made even more impressive at a time when many—
including this publication—feared that the University's public image was in decline. The new admissions figures suggest otherwise:
obviously a new group of some of the country's best students is more
than willing to take its chances at Hopkins, and at a minimum of
$16,000 a year. Admissions has clearly done an excellent job of drawing a bevy of impressive applicants. Now the tricky part: Why is
it, as Director of Admissions Rit Fuller noted, that Johns Hopkins
is "at the tail end with our peer institutions in terms of accepted
students who enroll"?
One obvious answer is that Hopkins lacks the prestige of Harvard
or Yale or Stanford, which is not exactly news. But if the University
can't beat those schools at their own game—name brand recognition
and word-of-mouth advertising—it might try to make a name for itself
in some other categories.
Campus Diversity—Kobi Little's observation on page 2 that
Hopkins "is not keeping pace with other universities of its caliber"
on issues of minority recruiting and cultural awareness may seem
a tired issue, but it is undeniably correct. With all of the nascent
movements to promote awareness and tolerance within the University community, only the Black Student Union has been a consistent
advocate of more far-reaching recruiting efforts in the ongoing search
for qualified freshmen. Admissions can point proudly to its large,
varied Asian-American and foreign-student populations—why not extend the diversity further, and include greater numbers of AfricanAmericans and Hispanics? This is easier said than done, the NewsLetter realizes, but diversity and tolerance are also easier to appreciate
in an environment that puts its minorities in the majority.
Faculty Members—While the University continues to knock itself
out promoting its research-over-teaching ethic, discontent among
faculty members continues to move in silently and ominously, like
a fleet of enemy ships on the horizon. If President Richardson's incessant fundraising yields any fruit, it should go toward filling some
of the yawning holes in research and teaching-assistant funds—just
to name two—and as quickly as possible. Let no one in the administration think that a jump in applications means their work is finished,

or even relieved. Great minds and great teachers are being lost—
most recently William Freehling of the Department of History, who
took a position at another school because Hopkins, he said, is "a
research institution that doesn't give its faculty members what they
need to do research and teach responsibly." For those who didn't
know Dr. Freehling, imagine the loss of David Olton in Psychology,
Richard Macksey in the Humanities Center, or Steven David in
Political Science, and the void left by Freehling—especially in
teaching—is easier to appreciate. The University will have trouble
enough trying to replace one such talent. It ought to bend over
backwards to ensure that it doesn't lose another.
Community—Before Admissions sends out another of its elegantly
produced brochures to prospective students, it might consider asking the administration to loosen up the pursestrings for a new student union and a greater HOP budget, to name only two pressing
needs. More students at Hopkins take it for granted that their peers
are a little cold; that yeah, a lot are just plain jerks; and that they
don't often get a chance to meet people. It doesn't have to be so dire.
The News-Letter believes that a campus spot for after-hours dancing
and (yes, we'll say it) drinking would do wonders for the atmosphere
here at Hopkins. It may not be priority—student concerns never are—
but administrators looking for a more cohesive, active student community could hardly spend their money in a better way. And it will
pay off in spades when prospectives come and actually find the people having fun.
Disconnected as these three phenomena might seem; they all directly
affect the atmosphere at—and eventually the public image of—the
University. A diverse student population sets a good example for
other schools and suggests that Hopkins' commitment to providing
quality education is more than skin- or checkbook-deep. Support for
faculty members encourages better teaching, which yields bettereducated students, which yields a better image for the University.
And a more tightly knit student community would benefit everyone
from Admissions to Zeniada.
Small improvements? Perhaps. But if a better Johns Hopkins is
the goal—and we optimistically hope it is—we should shoot for standards that have more resonance than SAT scores, and more depth
than an Ivy League reputation. If that won't attract talented incoming freshmen, then perhaps we don't want 'em.

Curious About the Middle East?
Want to Learn How it all Started?
The Near Eastern Studies Department will be offering the following courses in the Fall Semester. Four of these courses are given
entirely in English, require no knowledge of a foreign language, and have no prerequisites:

130.101 (H) Ancient Near Eastern Civilizations (3), MW 10 Schwartz
An introduction to the entire ancient Near East, from the first prehistoric farming communities to Alexander the Great. Learn about
the first cities and the first empires known. Includes the Sumerians, Babylonians, Assyrians, Hittites, Hurrians, Israelites, Egyptians,
Phoenicians, and Persians. If you want to understand the roots of conflict in the Middle East, this is the place to start!

130.301 (H) History of Ancient Syria-Palestine, including Israel (3), M 3-5 McCarter
Focuses on the area of modern Syria, Lebanon, Israel and Jordan. Discover the great early civilizations of Syria, including the revolutionary
finds from Ebla. Learn how our own alphabet originated in the second millennium BC. Study the emergence of ancient Israel and its interaction
with its neighbors. Evaluate the Old Testament as a historical source. In this course, you will do it all!

130.305 (H) Law in the Ancient World (3), TTh 3 Westbrook
Our modern concepts of law and justice can be traced directly back to the ancient world. This course will survey the legal systems of the ancient
Near East and early Greece and Rome from the earliest known records through the fifth century BC. Reading assignments will focus on original
documents, like the Code of Hammurabi, in English translation. Taught by a lawyer, the course will compare the legal concepts of the world's
oldest known systems with those of modern law.

130.391 (H) Jewish Literature and Civilization (2), W 11-12:30 Smolar
Study Jewish literature in translation from early post-biblical times to the present as a mirror of religious and social development, political
theory, and philosophical diversity. Taught by the president of the Baltimore Hebrew University.
If you like learning new languages, and have been intrigued by Egyptian hieroglyphs or the wedge-shaped cuneiform signs on Babylonian clay
tablets, you might want to try the following courses. Although they have graduate numbers, undergraduates who apply themselves should have
no difficulty completing them successfully.

132.600 (H) Elementary Akkadian (4), TBA Westbrook
The language of ancient Babylonia and Assyria, written in cuneiform script. After an introduction to the script and grammar, beginners are
soon reading texts that form the basis of Western culture, such as the Flood story and the first great law code.

133.600 (H) Hieroglyphs: Script and Language of Ancient Egypt (4), TBA Galan
An introduction to Middle Egyptian, the classical language of Egyptian hieroglyphs. The same language that was written by King Tut and
Ramses the Great, it is taught at only a handful of universities. A year will make you conversant enough to read some short stories, a few of the
world's first medical texts, and inscriptions from statues in museums (amaze your friends!).
You may think you know Hebrew, but until you've studied the language of the Bible on its own terms, you only know part of the story. The
following course will introduce you to the Hebrew of the Bible, unencumbered by post-biblical accretions:

130.440 Elementary Biblical Hebrew (3), TBA Scott

Fifty Students Pack
Meals for Homeless
by Kathleen Curry
On March 14, shelters for the
homeless in the Baltimore City
area received bagged meals
assembled by fifty Hopkins
students. This initiative on the
part of Student Council was
organized by Freshman Class
Representative Margaret Lee,
who was asked to head the Food
Drive Committee at the beginning of second semester.
In less than two months, with
some advising from the United
Way, Lee raised enough funding
from local bakeries, grocery
stores, and a freshman class dorm
contest to bag over one thousand
lunches consisting of sandwiches,
popcorn, candy and an apple.
"I really didn't know anything
about Baltimore when I began
this project," said Lee. "So I
began by working with Dee Klein
at the United Way, and also made
an effort not to conflict with
Salvation Army programs."
The bags went to six shelters,
including St. Mark's, Antiarc,
and St. Anne's. Although the
Salvation Army offers a food van
service, there is still a great demand for resources from the
community.
"Many shelters are still in
need," explained Lee. "I think
they really appreciated seeing that
Hopkins cares."
Lee recognizes, however, that
campus awareness of issues concerning the greater Baltimore
community is always in need of
improvement.
"We have to recognize that
there is a whole world outside of
this campus. Apathy is probably

the biggest problem. People don't
know how much power they really have to affect change, but we
need to take an active interest in
making a difference because we
can, and we have."
Although Lee realizes that the
future of such programs will be
dependent on the new Student
Council's agenda, she would like
to see these efforts continued.
"I'd like to see a lot more
students get involved in community efforts to work against
poverty and homelessness," she
said.
Ms. Lee noted her great thanks
to the Student Council, Bob
Nelson, the United Way, and all
those who came to help bag the
meals.
"Everybody's contribution was
extremely important," she concluded. "I couldn't have accomplished this without their
support."

While paper disposables may at
first appear more environmentally
sound than those of polystyrene,
neither is a true solution to the
trash problem. No disposable cup
can prove itself ecologically
sound when compared to reusable
china. It's unrealistic, however,

eliminated; given such a situation, paper products are
preferable to those of
polystyrene.
From the beginning, polystyrene presents environmental
problems that are more serious
than those presented by producing paper. The most serious of
these is the use of pentane,
styrene, and benzene. Pentane is
now used as a blowing agent instead of the ozone-depleting
chlorofluorocarbons. While pentane does little or no damage to
the ozone in the stratosphere, it
creates ozone at ground level.
Ozone at this level is a contributor

to smog and has been proven to
cause lung damage and immune
system problems. Pentane is also
highly explosive and creates job
hazards in the factories. Other job
hazards associated with the production of polystyrene include
skin diseases, cancer, lung problems, and kidney diseases. Of
chemicals produced in the United
States, polystyrene production
creates the fifth largest amount of
hazardous waste.
There are problems with producing paper cups. First is the
resources required. While wood
is a renewable resource, current
logging practices are exceedingly poor. Clearcutting is a problem
with all wood-related products.
Still, sustainable logging practices
do exist, which, if more widely
used, would allow the harvesting
of trees without undue damage to
the environment. The other problem is that paper production is
inefficient. One answer is to use
recycled paper. Although producing paper requires more energy

Men's Lacrosse Loses to Tarheels
by Jay Friedman
CHAPEL HILL, April 6—
It was one of the most anticipated games of the season.
Powerful offense against stifling
defense. The top two teams in
Division I lacrosse squared off in
a battle for national bragging
rights. Unfortunately for the Blue
Jays, the top-ranked Tar Heels of
the University of North Carolina
can brag—for now. The Tar
Heels defeated Hopkins 11-6
beneath a Carolina blue sky to remain undefeated and top ranked.
In a game that was closer than the
score indicated, Carolina (7-0)
used a third-quarter surge to pull
ahead of the Jays 8-4 in front of
5700 fans at Fetzer Field. At least
the Blue Jays finished the
toughest stretch of their schedule
(Syracuse in the Carrier Dome,
then No. 1 UVa, and at NO. 1
UNC)with two victories. That's
two more than the experts
predicted before the season
started as all three teams were
ranked above Hopkins. At 4-2 on
the year the Jays are now the
fourth ranked team, behind
Carolina, Princeton, and Brown.
Hopkins jumped out to a 2-0
lead 4 minutes and 38 seconds into the game on goals 29 seconds

apart. Junior Jeff Wills opened
the scoring off a cross field feed
from Matt Panetta. After the goal
Carolina was called for unnecessary roughness and the Jays
scored on the ensuing extra-man
opportunity. Panetta, at the top of
the restraining box, found Seth
Tierney, playing with a broken
wrist for the second week, in
front of the cage where he released a five-yard shot over UNC
goalie Andy Piazza's shoulder.
The Hopkins offense looked like
it was about to continue where it
left off after last week's Virginia
victory but that was not to be.
Playing on their home grass
field (beautifully manicured to
look like a golf fairway), the Tar
Heels used their deep bench and
overall team speed to control the
tempo of the game until the final
buzzer. After tying the game two
minutes later on goals 18 seconds
apart, UNC began dictating play.
Although the Heels did do a good
job of keeping Hopkins in the
game thoughout the first half by
failing to convert several fast
break opportunities and missing
the 6x6 on still more, they seemed to be slowly taking control of
the game. The final statistics
would suggest the same; the Jays
were outshot 51-35 for the after-

noon. Of those, Hopkins put 23
on net compared to Carolina's 31.
Given the chance, Hopkins
took the lead back at 3-2 on an
incredibly no-angle shot by Brendan Cody. The play was a great
individual effort but it marked the
beginning of the end. Without the
cutting and the movement from
the other players on the offensive
end the Jays were bound to get into trouble. But while Hopkins
looked to get back in the swing
they were missing their own

Before capturing last year's
National League West crown,
the Cincinnati Reds were the
Ohio version of the Mets (see last

they could win down the stretch,
the Reds must be considered contenders once again.
Player for player, there are few
teams in baseball that can even
compare to the Reds, including
Oakland. Last year's World
Series was not a fluke. It was
simply a case of one talented team
being hotter than another. What
was amazing about the Reds'
1990 accomplishments was that
they were in spite of, not because
of, OF Eric Davis(.260, 24 HR,
80 RBI, 21 SB). If Davis could

homers and steals. With Davis
struggling, SS Barry Larkin
(.301, 30 SB), 38 Chris Sabo(25

(78 RBI)picked up the slack. 1B
Hal Morris (.340) and 2B Bill
Doran (.373 with Cincinatti) are
solid role players. The bench is
loaded, as 2B Mariano Duncan
(.306) and OF Glenn Braggs
would probably start on another
club.

put it together last year, appearing nearly unhittable in the
playoffs. He'll be joined in the
rotation by Tom Browning
(15-9), Jack Armstrong (11-3
before All-Star break, 1-6 after),
Scott Scudder and Chris Hammond. Scudder and Hammond

Men's Eight Captures First
Place at JHU Invitational
by Richard Safranek
The Johns Hopkins men's and
women's crews enjoyed mixed
results at their only home race of
the year, the Johns Hopkins Invitational. The men's lighweight
eight posted the best finish of the
day, taking first in a close race
against boats from George
Washington University and
LaSalle, while the men's novice
eight finished third in their division. Despite strong rowing in the
preliminary heats, both the men's
heavyweight four and the
women's novice eight failed to
qualify for the finals, while the
women's heavyweight four did
not compete because of an injury
to one of its rowers.
The men's lightweight eight
gave the small but vocal crowd
of Hopkins supporters plenty of
excitement when they fell behind
early to George Washington, but
the men's eight maintained its
composure, gradually overtaking
George Washington for the win.
"I was really pleased with the
way we rowed, because when we
fell behind early we didn't panic.
That was an area we were hoping to improve in from last week.
When we needed power, we got
it, and we managed to gain on,
and eventually take George
Washington," said senior cocaptain Rob Porcarelli.
Unfortunately for Hopkins, the
other boats of the crew failed to
match the success of the
lightweight eight, most likely due
to the fact that Hopkins was
distracted by having to host the
regatta. As host, the members of
the crew were responsible for
such logistics as assembling the
course, repairing the starting
docks, handling concessions at
the race, and providing lodging
for over 150 visiting rowers. The
distractions of hosting the regatta were a definite handicap for
some of Hopkins' rowers.
"We definitely expected to do
a lot better," said junior Eric

Plautz, a member of the men's
heavyweight four. "I think
hosting tired us out mentally and
physically. It was draining
because there were a lot of things
to do and worry about."
Although the women's novice
eight failed to qualify for the
finals, freshman coxswain
Stephanie Fishkin felt her boat
continued to gain experience at
the regatta.
"I think we rowed really well
last week. I see a lot of improvement each week we row, and I
think we're going to continue to
get better," said Fishlcin.
The overall Hopkins performance was most certainly affected by the absence of the
women's heavyweight four,
which was expected to cruise to
an easy victory at the Invitational.
The women's four was forced to
withdraw when a team member,
junior Jen Ehringer, developed
back problems.
"It was really disappointing not
being able to row because we
knew we could win, but it was
just one of those things you can't
control," said senior Kathleen
McCabe, a rower on the
women's four.
The women's four hopes to
have Ehringer back this week so
they can row at the George
Washington Invitational, where
they will face such crews as
George Washington and Carnegie
Mellon. The race is especially
important for the women because
its results help to determine the
all-important seedings for the
Dad Vail Regatta at the end of the
year.
The men's heavyweight four
will hope to improve upon last
week's performance although
they will face a very competitive
field, including boats from
Georgetown, Navy, and George
Washington.
"I think we've had a few problems that we've worked out, so
I think we have a good chance of
doing fairly well," said Plautz.
